column1: In the last two days, Tesla shares have fallen 15.3 percent. Such a two-day loss has occurred only six times since the electric car maker's IPO in 2010. A week after those losses, it returned an average of 3.96 percent, trading positively about 67 percent of the time, according to Kensho, a hedge fund analytics tool.Past returns do not guarantee future results, and worries about Tesla's ability to meet bond payments could make this time different.
column2: Adamas Pharmaceuticals Inc. (ADMS) reported a loss of $35 million in its first quarter. The results exceeded Wall Street expectations. In the final minutes of trading on Thursday, shares hit $29.76, a rise of 75 percent in the last 12 months. The drugmaker posted revenue of $2.6 million in the period, which also beat Street forecasts..
column3: John Giannandrea, Google's senior vice president of engineering, is stepping down after two years on the job. His role will now be split between two executives. Jeff Dean, the cofounder of Google Brain, will lead all of the company's AI efforts. Ben Gomes, who joined Google in 2000 and was running search engineering, will take over the search organization. The move suggests that AI is now important enough to form its own business unit.
column4: Cathay General Bancorp is the holding company for Cathay Bank, a California state-chartered bank. The Board of Directors declared a cash dividend of twenty-four cents per common share, payable on , to stockholders of record at the close of business on . Founded in 1962,Cathay Bank currently operates 41 branches in California, 12 branches in New York State, three in the Chicago, Illinois area and three in Washington State
column5: The Wall Street Journal reports that Boeing is close to a deal to buy KLX. The report said a deal could be announced Monday, though it could also fall through. Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg said in March that the company was looking into an acquisition of Embraer.Muilenburg: "We are making progress, still have some work to do but I am hopeful that we can bring that deal to a successful close"
column6: "Black Panther" crossed the $1 billion mark at the box office this weekend. The film is the first to stay in the top box-office slot for four straight weeks. It earned $66.5 million in its first three days in China. It is the highest grossing film by a black director and the largest February debut of all time. It's also the second largest Marvel debut (after The Avengers)
column7: Federal agents are interviewing employees of Wells Fargo 's wealth management division. The FBI has interviewed some employees in the Phoenix area. Wells acknowledged widespread problems with sales practices in 2016. The bank created 3.5 million accounts without customers' knowledge as retail division employees pursued aggressive sales targets. The government asked Wells Fargo to begin an investigation into sales practices at its Wells Fargo Advisors unit after whistleblowers flagged problems in sales.
column8: Yulia Skripal to be discharged from British hospital, Sky News says. The two were poisoned with a nerve agent in Salisbury, U.K., last month. On Friday, doctors said the health of Yulia, 33, and her father SergeiSkripal had improved rapidly in the last few weeks after they were found unconscious on a bench on March 4 in the southern English city of Salisbury.
column9: FLEETCOR Technologies will host a conference call to discuss first quarter financial results on Thursday, at 5:00 pm ET. Hosting the call will be Ron Clarke, chief executive officer, Eric Dey, chief financial officer and Jim Eglseder, investor relations. The conference call can be accessed live over the phone by dialing (855) 327-6837, or for international callers (631) 891-4304.
column10: Clipper Realty Inc. will release financial results for the quarter and year ended , after the market closes on Thursday, . The Company will host a conference call that same day at 5:00 PM (ET) to discuss the financial results. The conference call can be accessed by dialing 800-346-7359 or 1-973-528-0008, conference entry code 102845.
column11: Amazon's report is due out after the bell on Thursday. The revelation that the company now has 100 million Amazon Prime members globally was a huge boost for the stock last week. Any sharp dip would be a buying opportunity for investors, says Tom Zoellner, CEO of e-commerce giant Zoellners. The company's stock is up 60 percent in the last year and trading above $1,450 per share.
column12: Crown Holdings, Inc. will release its earnings for the first quarter ended after the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday, . The Company will hold a conference call to discuss these results at 9:00 a.m. (EDT) on Thursday, and the access password is "packaging" A replay of the conference call will be available for a one-week period ending at midnight on April
column13: Softbank is reshaping Silicon Valley and the entire tech industry. The Japanese company is investing billions of dollars in tech companies. Last year, Softbank invested in more than half of the top 10 biggest investments in VC-backed start-ups, including WeWork, Flipkart, and ride-hailing giants Didi Chuxing, Grab and Ola. Softbank's Vision Fund is the biggest technology investment fund in history.
column14: New Gold Inc. will release its year-end 2017 financial results after market close on . A webcast and conference call to discuss these results will be held on Wednesday, at 10:00 a.m. Eastern time. Participants may listen to the webcast by registering on our website at . You may alsoListen to the conference call by calling toll free 1-888-231-8191, or 1-
column15: iStar declares quarterly dividends on the Company's outstanding shares of Preferred Stock. Dividends are payable on to holders of record on . iStar is structured as a real estate investment trust ("REIT"), with a diversified portfolio focused on larger assets located in major metropolitan markets. The Company has more than two decades of experience and more than $35 billion of transactions.
column16: The dividend will be payable on , to stockholders of record on . This is the 54th successive quarterly dividend that Westlake has declared since completing its initial public offering in August 2004. The company's range of products includes: ethylene, polyethylene, styrene, propylene, chlor-alkali and derivative products, PVC suspension and specialty resins, PVC Compounds and PVC building products.
column17: U.S. defense contractor CACI International withdrew its offer to buy peer CSRA on Wednesday. General Dynamics raised its all-cash offer for CSRA to $6.9 billion. CSRA provides information technology and related services to the Department of Defense and intelligence community. CACi's stock fell 7.5 percent a day after it offered to buy CSRA for $15 per share in cash.
column18: Yellen says the U.S. central bank is likely to need to continue to raise interest rates gradually. She hands the reins to President Donald Trump's pick to replace her, Governor Jerome Powell. She will stay in Washington as a fellow at the Brookings Institution, the think tank where former Fed Chair Ben Bernanke also works."The economy is growing at a healthy, solid pace," Yellen said.
column19: The board of directors of Eli Lilly and Company (NYSE: LLY) has declared a dividend for the second quarter of 2018 of $0.5625 per share on outstanding common stock. The dividend is payable , to shareholders of record at the close of business on . Lilly is a global healthcare leader that unites caring with discovery to make life better for people around the world.
column20: GenMark Diagnostics Inc. (GNMK) on Tuesday reported a loss of $14.5 million in its fourth quarter. The results fell short of Wall Street expectations. The molecular diagnostics company posted revenue of $16 million in the period. For the year, the company reported that its loss widened to $61.9 million, or $1.21 per share. The company's shares hit $4.89 in final minutes of trading on Tuesday.
column21: Eli Lilly and Company will announce its financial results for the first quarter of 2018 on Tuesday, . Lilly will also conduct a conference call with the investment community and media to further detail the company's financial performance. The conference call will begin at 9 a.m. Eastern time. Investors, media and the general public can access a live webcast of the conference call through a link that will be posted on Lilly's website.
column22: AMN Healthcare Services Inc. (AMN) on Thursday reported first-quarter earnings of $42.7 million. The results topped Wall Street expectations. The health care staffing company posted revenue of $522.5 million in the period. For the current quarter ending in July, AMN Healthcare said it expects revenue in the range of $530 million to $537 million. shares hit $64.80, a rise of 58 percent in the last 12 months.
column23: J.P. Morgan Chase is shopping for an exchange-traded fund firm, Bloomberg reports. WisdomTree stock closed at $10.41 Friday following the report and is up more than 18 percent year over year. More than $23 billion of investor money entered the market in July, putting ETFs in the U.S. over the $3 trillion mark in assets under management.
column24: UBS predicts Apple's iPhone sales growth in China will be roughly flat this fiscal year. The analyst said Apple's China sales peaked in 2015, when the country represented 25 percent of iPhone shipments. "We expect a flattish market, give or take a few points of growth depending on the overall market and product cycle," he wrote. Despite the company's growth issues in China, the analyst reiterated his buy rating and $190 price target for Apple shares.
column25: Delphi Technologies PLC declares a quarterly cash dividend of $0.17 per ordinary share. The dividend is payable on , to the shareholders of record on . Delphi Technologies is a technology company focused on providing electric vehicle and internal combustion engine propulsion solutions. With headquarters in London, U.K., the company operates technical centers, manufacturing sites and customer support services in 24 countries.
column26: Japanese automakers have created jobs and made huge contributions to the U.S. economy, Shinzo Abe says. The number of cars Japanese automakers produce in the United States is double the number it exports to the country. Abe also says Tokyo will continue to urge Washington to join the multilateral Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) He says Japan believes that any steps taken on trade must be in line with World Trade Organization rules.
column27: Leon Cooperman is the chairman and CEO of Omega Advisors hedge fund. He owns stakes in Facebook , Amazon , Netflix and Google, according to a recent SEC filing. The Omega chief likes Alphabet in particular, saying it has a fortress-like balance sheet. The billionaire investor expects moderate gains for the tech sector in 2018, he said. He doesn't own shares of Apple, he told CNBC.
column28: GSI Technology Inc. (GSIT) reported a fiscal third-quarter loss of $1.5 million. The Sunnyvale, California-based company said it had a loss of 7 cents per share. The chipmaker posted revenue of $11.1 million in the period. For the current quarter ending in March, GSI Technology said it expects revenue in the range of $10 million to $11 million.
column29: HRG Group, Inc. will issue a press release reporting its results for the fiscal first quarter ended . The press release and any other financial supplement information (if any) will be available online by visiting under the Investor Relations section of the website. HRG is headquartered in New York and traded on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol HRG.
column30: "Tide Pod Challenge" has received 435,119 mentions on social media since Dec. 23. On average daily, it's receiving 14,036 mentions a day. The challenge asks teens to swallow the laundry detergent pods. The Tide brand's corporate parent, Procter & Gamble, has vigorously sought to swipe down the challenge, even bringing in Rob Gronkowski to support its efforts.
column31: Simmons Bank, as Trustee of the Cross Timbers Royalty Trust (NYSE:CRT), today declared a cash distribution to the holders of its units of beneficial interest of $0.131107 per unit. The distribution is payable on , to unitholders of record on . Underlying cumulative excess costs remaining on the Texas Working Interest net profits interests after the current month's distribution totaled $2.0 million.
column32: Rowley Law PLLC is investigating potential claims against Juno Therapeutics, Inc. and its board of directors. The proposed acquisition of the company by Celgene Corporation is valued at approximately $9 billion. Stockholders will receive $87.00 for each share of Juno. that they hold. If you are a stockholder of Juno and are interested in obtaining additional information regarding this investigation, please visit us at:
column33: The GE9X engine lifted off Wednesday, under the wing of GE Aviation's Boeing 747 flying test-bed in Victorville, California. The test had been delayed from February after engineers discovered a design issue with the turbofan. The engine has approximately the same diameter as the fuselage of a Boeing 737 and houses a 134-inch-diameter front fan, that GE has claimed is the largest of any commercial engine in production.
column34: Zuckerberg visited every U.S. state, ran 365 miles and learned Mandarin since he first started doing these annual challenges in 2009. Social media companies including Twitter have been pressured by regulators and the European Union to take more steps to remove hate speech on their platforms. Facebook has faced harsh criticism over its failure to prevent Russian operatives from using its platform for meddling in the 2016 U.N. elections.
column35: Villanova wins its second title in three seasons with a 79-62 win over Michigan. Donte DiVincenzo scored 31 points, including nine straight in the second half. Villanova has won all six games by double digits in this tournament run. It's the fourth time the Wildcats have won the title in the last three years, following in 2000, 2001 and 2009. The game was played in San Diego.
column36: Ionis Pharmaceuticals Inc. (IONS) reported a first-quarter loss of $1.4 million. On a per-share basis, the Carlsbad, California-based company said it had a loss of 1 cent. The results surpassed Wall Street expectations. The drug discovery and development company posted revenue of $144.4m in the period. It did not meet Street forecasts.
column37: Rowley Law PLLC is investigating potential claims against La Quinta Holdings Inc. Stockholders will receive $8.40 in cash for each share that they hold. The proposed sale of the hotel franchise and hotel management businesses to Wyndham Worldwide Corporation is valued at approximately $1.95 billion. If you are a stockholder and are interested in obtaining additional information regarding this investigation, please visit us at:
column38: The $0.02 per share dividend will be paid on to shareholders of record at the close of business on . This is the Company's fifty-ninth consecutive quarterly cash dividend. With the payment of this dividend, the Company will have paid a total of $472.4 million in cash dividends, including three special dividends since the dividend program was implemented in the third quarter of 2003.
column39: Icahn, who owns about 13.5 percent of SandRidge and is the company's single largest shareholder, said he had "grave concerns" about current directors. The current board "had a history of making poor decisions on behalf of stockholders," Icahn wrote in a filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.SandRidge shares have fallen 37 percent this year. They closed down 10 cents at $13.34 on Wednesday.
column40: PBF Energy Inc. will release its earnings results for the fourth quarter 2017 on Thursday, . The company will host a conference call and webcast regarding fourth quarter results and other business matters. The call is being webcast and can be accessed at PBF Energy's website, . The audio replay will be available two hours after the end of the call through , by dialing (800) 283-
column41: Arbutus Biopharma Corporation (Nasdaq:ABUS) will hold a conference call on Wednesday, at 1:30 PM Pacific Time. The company will discuss fourth quarter 2017 year-end financial results and provide a corporate update. To access the conference call, a live webcast of the call can be accessed through the Investor section of Arbutus' website at
column42: A Curacao court has authorized ConocoPhillips to seize about $636 million in assets belonging to Venezuela's state oil company PDVSA. The legal action was the latest in the Caribbean to enforce a $2 billion arbitration award by the International Chamber of Commerce (ICC) over the nationalization of the U.S. oil major's projects in Venezuela. The court decision, first reported by Caribbean media outlet Antilliaans Dagblad on Saturday, says Cur
column43: Saudi Aramco will be ready for an initial public offering in the second half of 2018. A successful IPO could give the company a total valuation of up to $2 trillion. Saudi Arabia is planning to list up to 5 percent of Saudi Aramco in the offering. The company could be floated either domestically or internationally late this year, Saudi Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih said last week.
column44: Millicom will announce its first quarter results for the period ending 31 March 2018 on 24 April 2018. The company will host a conference call for the global financial community on 25 April 2018 at 14:00 (Stockholm) / 13:000 (London) / 08:00(New York) The conference call will be webcast at The access code for the call is 6273539.
column45: Hologic, Inc. plans to release its financial results for the second quarter of fiscal 2018 on Wednesday, , after the market closes. In conjunction with the release, management will host a conference call that day at 4:30 p.m. Eastern Time. Interested participants may listen to the call by dialing 800-239-9838 (in the United States) or +1 323-794-2551 (for international callers)
column46: Synopsys Inc. (SNPS) on Wednesday reported fiscal second-quarter net income of $102.5 million. The maker of software used to test and develop chips posted revenue of $776.8 million in the period. For the current quarter ending in August, Synopsys expects its per-share earnings to range from 89 cents to 93 cents. The company said it expects revenue in the range of $760 million to $785 million for the fiscal third quarter.
column47: ACE Cash Express, Inc. will provide financial results for the year ended on . The Company will host a conference call for Noteholders on Tuesday, , at 10:00 a.m. CT to discuss the financial results. ACE provides a range of retail financial products and services including short-term consumer loans, check cashing, card services, money transfers, bill payments and money orders.
column48: NW Natural declares quarterly dividend of 47.25 cents per share on the Company's common stock. Dividends will be paid to shareholders of record on . The Company's indicated annual dividend rate is $1.89 per share. NW Natural provides natural gas service to nearly 740,000 residential, commercial, and industrial customers in western Oregon and southwestern Washington.
column49: U.S. companies will be required to put down a 178.6 percent deposit for sorghum shipments to the country. The deposit, which trade experts said will act as a duty, is effective from Wednesday. The move follows the launch of an anti-dumping investigation just over two months ago into imports of the ingredient used in livestock feed and the fiery Chinese liquor baijiu. The government said it will issue a final ruling at a later date.
column50: Small-cap stocks typically benefit when the dollar gains in value. Smaller companies deal with more domestic sales, typically without the burden of having to translate overseas revenue back into dollar terms. Small-cap companies also should feel benefits from tax reform, Stacey Gilbert said Tuesday on "Trading Nation" Options in the IWM and the SPY are trading relatively close to the same price as a percent of their underlying index price.
column51: The concept fridge has been in development for several years. Unlike oil based plastics, bioplastics come from renewable sources including corn or sugarcane. The carbon footprint of the bioplastic in the refrigerator is over 80 percent lower compared to conventional plastics. Electrolux's ambition is to "develop even more innovative, sustainable home appliances," the firm said in a statement earlier this week.
column52: Senate Democrats say there is no evidence of specific, credible threats against Administrator Scott Pruitt. That's despite "unprecedented" number of threats against Pruitt, they say. The EPA has spent $3 million on Pruitt's security. The White House says it is investigating the claims. The Senate is considering a bill that would require the EPA to provide Pruitt with more security. It's the first time the White House has made such a request.
column53: Attorney General Jeff Sessions says he has ordered an immediate review of the processes at the Department of Justice and the FBI. The FBI acknowledged that it had received a tip about the suspect, but had not followed its own protocol for looking into such reports. Florida Gov. Rick Scott called the FBI's response to the tip "unacceptable" and called for Christopher Wray's resignation. "We constantly promote 'see something, say something,' and a courageous person did just that to the FBI,"
column54: Lennar reported higher first-quarter revenue and profit as it sold more homes at higher prices. The company's shares were up 2.2 percent at $58.34 in premarket trading.Orders, a key indicator of future revenue for homebuilders, rose 30.4 percent to 8,456 homes. The average sales price rose 7.7 percent to $393,000.
column55: Vladimir Putin tells NBC News he "couldn't care less" if citizens of his country meddled in the 2016 U.S. elections because they were not linked to the Kremlin. 13 Russian nationals and three Russian entities were indicted last month for alleged illegal interference in the presidential elections. Putin denies he was behind the interference which resulted in Donald Trump becoming President. "So what if they're Russians?" Putin said of the indictment. "There are 146 million Russians. So what
column56: Elon Musk announced on Wednesday that he was leaving his role as chief executive of Tesla. He had been in charge of the company since 2010, when it was founded. Musk's departure is the latest in a string of high-profile departures from the company in recent years. The company has also been hit by a series of technical problems, including a problem with the power supply to its solar panels.
column57: Cyprus company sues ex-Trump campaign manager for financial fraud. Surf Horizon filed a claim that former Trump campaign manager Paulafort and partner Richard Gates misappropriated funds the company invested in Ukrainian telecom companies.afort and Gates are already under criminal indictment by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, who has accused them of failing to register as foreign agents, conspiring to commit money launder and conspiring to defraud the United States.
column58: Parker Drilling Company declares a cash dividend of $1.8125 per share on its 7.25% Series A Mandatory Convertible Preferred Stock. The dividend is for the period beginning on , and ending on . The Company's Drilling Services business serves operators in the inland waters of the U.S. Gulf of Mexico utilizing Parker Drilling's barge rig fleet.
column59: Tesla doubled its service capacity in 2017, especially through expansion of its "mobile service fleet" The fleet now includes 230 vehicles that travel to customers throughout North America, so they don't have to bring their cars into the shop. Tesla plans to invest more in its mobile service, and other technology which allows it to remotely diagnose issues with its Model 3 sedans. In the past, Tesla has struggled to offer timely repairs to its customers.
column60: Amazon is offering Prime members who use its Visa rewards card 5 percent cash back when they shop at Whole Foods. Prime members in the U.S. get 5 percent back on all Amazon.com purchases, 2 percent back at restaurants, gas stations and drugstores. Non-Prime members will get 3 percent back when using their credit card. Amazon acquired Whole Foods last year for $13.7 billion.
column61: Carolinas Associated General Contractors is the construction industry association in the Carolinas. CAGC brings value to our thousands of members through networking, government relations, job leads, meetings with owners/designers, education and training. Visit us at , connect with us on Twitter , Facebook , YouTube , and LinkedIn. For more information, visit or call 704/372-1450.
column62: "Fast Money" traders share their first moves for the market open. Tim Seymour was a buyer of European Financials. David Seaburg bought Dermira. Dan Nathan was short the iShares Russell 2000 ETF. Guy Adami was a buyers of Con Edision. The following stocks and commodities mentioned or intended to be mentioned on CNBC's " fast money" were owned by the "Fast money" traders.
column63: San Francisco Federal Reserve President John Williams will take the reins of the New York Fed in June. A trade war could not only hurt economic growth but could also lead to an undesirable rise in inflation, he added. "If we were to try to unwind all of that it would be extremely disruptive and very costly, both for the U.S. and the world," Williams said in an interview.
column64: U.S. retailer Gap apologizes for selling a T-shirt which it said had an incorrect map of China. It added it would implement "rigorous reviews" to prevent a repeat mistake. The apology came after a person posted pictures of the T-shirts on Chinese social media network Weibo. China has been ramping up efforts to police language used to describe Chinese-claimed territories.
column65: McDonald's will ship 20 million packets of Szechuan sauce to all of its restaurants in the U.S. The condiment was first served by McDonald's in 1998 to promote the Disney film "Mulan" "Rick and Morty," a sci-fi comedy cartoon, featured the sauce in an episode. A petition signed by 38,742 people to bring back the product prompted McDonald's to reintroduce it.
column66: Boston Scientific forecast better-than-expected 2018 revenue. Medical device maker's fourth-quarter sales beat Wall Street estimates on higher sales in its cardiac rhythm management unit. Company incurred a $842 million charge due to changes in the U.S. tax law in the reporting quarter. The company reported a net loss of $615 million, or 45 cents per share, in the fourth quarter.
column67: Tower International, Inc. will report fourth quarter 2017 financial results before the market opens on . At 11:00 a.m. EST on that date, a conference call is scheduled to discuss the results in further detail, as well as other related matters. The conference call, along with the financial results release, presentation material and other supplemental information, can be accessed through Tower's Web site at
column68: The dividend will be payable on to stockholders of record as of . In the hydraulics market, the Company is a leading manufacturer of high-performance screw-in hydraulic cartridge valves, electro-hydraulics, manifolds, and integrated package solutions. Sun is a global provider of innovative electronic control, display and instrumentation solutions for both recreational and off-highway vehicles.
column69: Cisco Systems Inc. (CSCO) on Wednesday reported fiscal third-quarter earnings of $2.69 billion. Earnings, adjusted for one-time gains and costs, were 66 cents per share. The results beat Wall Street expectations. For the current quarter ending in July, Cisco expects its per-share earnings to range from 68 cents to 70 cents. The seller of routers, switches, software and services posted revenue of $12.46 billion.
column70: Ms. Renitalynette K. Anderson brings extensive senior-level management and technical experience from a distinguished 30-year career of Federal service. Ms. Anderson will provide leadership for QuTech's strategic growth and corporate operations. QuTech is an Information Technology company specializing in Cybersecurity, Data Center management, Cloud Computing, IT Service/Call Center management and Program Management with Federal, State, and Local Governments.
column71: Akamai reports earnings that beat Wall Street estimates for the fourth quarter. Total revenue for the cloud company rose 7.7 percent to $663.5 million. The company also announced it cut 400 positions, or 5 percent of its global workforce.Shares of Akamai are up 2.5 percent year to date, according to the company's stock price. The cloud company is owned by activist investor Elliott Management.
column72: President Donald Trump said Thursday that it would be a good idea to release the photographs of the meeting between then-CIA Director Mike Pompeo and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. White House press secretary Sarah Sanders did just that on Thursday afternoon. The photo release came hours after the Senate confirmed Pompeo as the next secretary of State. Trump said that Pompeo was not slated to meet with the leader of North but an opportunity was later arranged during the trip.
column73: CareDx Inc. (CDNA) on Thursday reported a loss of $31.7 million in its fourth quarter. The molecular diagnostics company posted revenue of $12.5 million in the period. CareDx expects full-year revenue in the range of $61 million to $63 million. In the final minutes of trading on Thursday, shares hit $5.98, more than quadrupling in the last year.
column74: Genuine Parts Company plans to release Fourth Quarter and Year-End Earnings on . Management will also conduct a conference call on this date at 11:00 a.m. Eastern time. The public may access the call on the Company's website, , by clicking "Investors" or by dialing 800-289-0438.
column75: Rowley Law PLLC is investigating potential claims against LaSalle Hotel Properties (NYSE: LHO) and its board of directors for breach of fiduciary duty. The proposed acquisition of the company by Blackstone is valued at approximately $4.8 billion and is expected to close third quarter of 2018. Stockholders will receive $33.50 for each share of LaSale Hotel Properties stock that they hold.
column76: Wendi Deng Murdoch could be using her ties to Jared Kushner and wife Ivanka Trump to aid the Chinese government, The Wall Street Journal reported. Counterintelligence officials also warned the Chinese-American businesswoman may have been lobbying for a construction project in Washington, D.C. A spokesman for Wendi Deng Murdoch told the Journal that the businesswoman "has no knowledge of any FBI concerns or other intelligence agency concerns"
column77: Canadian oil and gas producer Encana Corp posts better-than-expected adjusted profit. Company is in the middle of a five-year plan to boost its output growth rate. Production from core assets rose 32 percent to 313,200 barrels of oil equivalent per day (boe/d) in the quarter ended Dec. 31 from a year earlier. Realized prices for oil increased 4.3 percent to $52.94 per barrel.
column78: Apple's offer to replace flagging batteries at a slashed rate could be a hurdle for iPhone unit sales in 2018. Apple said last month it intentionally slowed down older iPhones to prevent them from shutting off abruptly. The company has since slashed the price of out-of-warranty replacement batteries to $29 from $79 for iPhone 6 or later models. Even a small percentage opting for battery replacement over upgrade could have meaningful impact on iPhone sales.
column79: Virtua Partners has purchased a 22 acre parcel in the City of Avondale in the West Valley of Phoenix. The parcel, located at W. Indian School Road and N. El Mirage Road, was purchased for $3.11MM. Virtua Partners Affiliate, Quyp Development, will be rezoning the land for residential and commercial uses. The location is ideal for both residential andcommercial uses in the growing Phoenix economy.
column80: Helen Zhao is a rotating business news associate at CNBC. She attended the Business News Associate Workshop at the AAJA Convention. Zhao: "I knew I wanted to be a business news journalist at the most multi-faceted environment possible""I definitely got this familial vibe that's been further cemented during my time here at CNBC," she says. "So, the workshop itself is just so dynamic, it's so interactive"
column81: City Football Group currently owns Manchester City, New York City and Melbourne City soccer clubs. It also operates more than 20 teams across those cities. Tom Glick, chief commercial officer of City Football Group, said his firm wants more clubs to add to its stable. Glick said China is a particular target for his firm because of its strengthening professional league, healthy TV audiences, and obvious government support.
column82: M/I Homes, Inc. is one of the nation's leading builders of single-family homes, having sold over 105,000 homes. The Company's homes are marketed and sold primarily under the trade names M/I. Homes and Showcase Collection. The call will be archived on the Web site
column83: A $45,000 salary might be sufficient for a family of three in South Dakota. You would need close to $60,000 on average to keep up in Hawaii, Connecticut, Massachusetts and New York. And a whopping $68,000 a year to get by in Washington D.C. That's according to data from MIT's living wage calculator, which determines the minimum amount necessary to meet basic needs without relying on outside help.
column84: Switch shares plummeted as much as 24 percent after hours. Cancer Genetics stock plunged more than 33 percent after the bell. CVD Equipment rallied more than 10 percent post-market after the research equipment manufacturer announced its best financial results throughout its 35-year history. The company plans to conduct a "comprehensive and extensive" review of its strategy and organization. The biotech company missed revenue estimates by nearly $2 million.
column85: The class action lawsuit alleged that the bank made certain misstatements and omissions in disclosures related to its sales practices. The lawsuit sought damages for investors who bought Wells Fargo stocks between February 2014 and September 2016. Wells Fargo had denied the claims and allegations and said it entered into an agreement to avoid the cost and disruption of further litigation. It also accused executives of trumpeting the bank's success at "cross-selling", while opening millions of accounts illegally.

Financial results will be issued in a news release at approximately 6:45 a.m. EST. column87: Harmonic (NASDAQ: HLIT) will release its first quarter 2018 financial results after the market close on Monday, . Harmonic will host a live webcast to discuss the company's results at 2:00 p.m. PT on the same day. An audio version of the webcast will be available by calling +1.800.240.9147 (passcode 6987705).
column88: Netflix split the DVD division from the streaming service in 2011. The company has barely more than 3 million DVD subscribers, compared to 125 million streaming subscribers. DVD.com showed an operating profit of $56 million on $99 million in revenue in the first quarter of 2018.DVD plans range from $5 to $12 a month, while streaming plans are $8-$14 a month. At the peak, there were 50 distribution centers. Now only 17 remain in the U.S.
column89: Alpha and Omega Semiconductor Ltd. (AOSL) on Wednesday reported fiscal third-quarter earnings of $1.7 million. On a per-share basis, the Sunnyvale, California-based company said it had net income of 7 cents. For the current quarter ending in June, Alpha and Omega said it expects revenue in the range of $106 million to $110 million.
column90: UGI Corporation will announce the results of its first fiscal quarter after the market closes on January 31. The company will hold a live internet audio webcast of its conference call to discuss results and other current activities at 9:00 AM EST on Thursday, February 1. A telephonic replay will be available from 12:00 PM EST on February 1 through 11:59 PM EST February 8.
column91: The bank released a research report called "Out on a Limb" on Thursday. The report includes a collection of contrarian stock investment ideas. The analysts included their theses for each suggestion as well as price targets and 12-month outlook. Here are three of their unusual picks: Ralph Lauren, Lululemon Athletica and L'OrÃ©al. The bank's research report is available on its website.

column93: Palatin Technologies, Inc. (NYSE American: PTN) will announce its second quarter, fiscal year 2018 operating results on Monday, before the open of the U.S. financial markets. Palatin will also conduct a conference call and live audio webcast hosted by its executive management team at 11:00 a.m. ET. The conference call will include a review of the company's operating results and an update on programs under development.
column94: Uber will not renew its permit to test autonomous vehicles on California public roads. California's Department of Motor Vehicles told the ride-hailing service it will lose testing privileges after Saturday. If Uber wants to return, it will need a new permit and has to address investigations into a fatal crash in Arizona last week. Uber decided last week to suspend tests on public roads in California, Pennsylvania, Arizona and Ontario.
column95: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company will report fourth quarter 2017 financial results on Thursday, Feb. 8. The company will post the financial and other related information that will be presented on its investor relations website: A taped replay will be available by calling (800) 839-2393 or (402) 220-7206. Goodyear is one of the world's largest tire companies. It employs approximately 64,000 people and manufactures
column96: Rowley Law PLLC is investigating potential claims against A. Schulman, Inc. and its board of directors for breach of fiduciary duty. The proposed acquisition of the company by LyondellBasell is valued at approximately $2.25 billion. Stockholders will receive $42.00 in cash and one contingent value right for each share they hold. The transaction is expected to close in the second half of 2018.
column97: Ooma Inc. (OOMA) on Tuesday reported a loss of $3.7 million in its fiscal first quarter. Losses, adjusted for one-time gains and costs, came to 4 cents per share. The results topped Wall Street expectations. Ooma expects revenue in the range of $30.5 million to $31.3 million for the fiscal second quarter. The internet phone service provider shares have climbed almost 3 percent since the beginning of the year.
column98: Shares in Riyadh-listed international investment company Kingdom Holding soared at the opening on Sunday. The stock immediately jumped its 10 percent daily limit to 10.04 riyals in unusually active trade. The Saudi stock index was flat, restrained by a 1.9 percent drop by top petrochemical producer Saudi Basic Industries, which fell 2.1 percent after reporting lower-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings.
